newsitem.title: USA: IRS issues technical advice on muni hospital bonds.
newsitem.headline: IRS issues technical advice on muni hospital bonds.

text.p: The Internal Revenue Service said that a hospital could not take an interest deduction for municipal bond proceeds that it mistakenly allocated to a for-profit clinic.

"A tax-exempt hospital may not set aside bond proceeds mistakenly allocated to a for-profit clinic or take a deduction for the bond interest (on) the proceeds used by the clinic," IRS said in a 13-page ruling.
The ruling, called a technical advice memorandum, says the hospital received private activity bonds to refund earlier bonds and reimburse capital expenditures.

"Due to an accounting mistake, the hospital allocated some of the bond proceeds to capital improvements for the clinic," IRS said. "Later, the hospital tried to re-allocate the proceeds in a paper transaction to correct the error."
The hospital argued that the change would not affect the "substance" of the allocation or the purpose of the bond issue, IRS said.
But the Service ruled, "The hospital may not re-allocate the proceeds to correct its mistakes."
It added that the hospital "engaged in an unrelated trade or business regarding the clinic's improper use of the bond proceeds and cannot take an interest deduction for those proceeds."
